text: These are people who certainly have not proved that they are worthy of the trust that we repose in them. As far as this job is concerned, let me also indicate that when it comes to BECE, most of the decisions are taken by the Ghana Education Service. For example, the selection of supervisors and invigilators is done by the district exams officer, he explained. His comments come in the wake of a JoyNews Hotline investigation led by GH Probe’s Francisca Enchil, which uncovered disturbing levels of collusion at examination centres.
translated: [Ni watu ambao hakuna ushahidi wazi kwamba wameonyesha kuwa wana thamani ya imani ambayo tumewapa. Kuhusu kazi hii, ninaomba pia nionyeshe kuwa wakati wa BECE, maamuzi mengi huchukuliwa na Huduma ya Elimu ya Ghana. Kwa mfano, uteuzi wa wasimamizi na wafanyakazi wa mtihani hufanywa na afisa wa mtihani wa wilaya, alieleza. Maoni yake yametolewa katika kipindi cha uchunguzi wa JoyNews Hotline ulioongozwa na Francisca Enchil wa GH Probe, ambao uligundua viwango vya kusikitisha vya ushirikiano katika vituo vya mtihani.]
backtranslated: [These are people who have not been proven to be worthy of the trust we have placed in them. Regarding this work, I would also like to point out that during the BECE, many decisions are made by the Ghana Education Ministry. For example, the selection of examination administrators and staff is done by district examination officers, he explained. His comments were made in a JoyNews Hotline survey conducted by Francisca Enchil of GH Probe, which found low levels of participation in the test centers.]

text: A variety of socioeconomic and cultural factors were identified as major barriers to accessing and utilizing MHCS. Over half of the women surveyed cited poverty, illiteracy, restrictions from their husbands, the distance to health facilities, and long queues as reasons for not using services. Additionally, over a third of the women pointed to cultural practices within their communities as a cause for delays in seeking care. These findings reveal that addressing maternal health in this region requires more than just improving clinical services; it also means tackling deeply rooted societal and personal challenges that women face daily.
translated: [Ndai ya mambo ya kiuchumi na kitamaduni yalitambuliwa kama vizuizi vikuu vya kupata na kutumia MHCS. Zaidi ya nusu ya wanawake waliohojiwa walitaja umaskini, ujuzi usio na elimu, vikwazo kutoka kwa waume wao, umbali wa vituo vya afya, na mizunguko ndefu kama sababu za kutotumia huduma. Zaidi ya hayo, zaidi ya theluthi moja ya wanawake walitaja mazoea ya kitamaduni ndani ya jamii zao kama sababu ya kupunguza kutafuta huduma. Matokeo haya yanaonyesha kwamba kushughulikia afya ya uzazi katika eneo hili linahitaji zaidi ya kuboresha tu huduma za kimatibabu; pia ina maana ya kushughulikia changamoto za kijamii na za kibinafsi zilizo na mizizi ya kina ambazo wanawake hukabiliana nazo kila siku.]
backtranslated: [Economic and cultural factors were identified as the main barriers to accessing and using MHCS. More than half of the women surveyed cited poverty, lack of education, obstacles from their husbands, distance from health centers, and long cycles as reasons for not using the service. Additionally, more than one-third of women cited cultural practices within their communities as reasons for reduced access to services. These results suggest that addressing reproductive health in this area requires more than just improving medical services; it also requires addressing the social and personal challenges that are at the root of many of the challenges women face every day.]

text: Despite his shortcomings, Unoka was a talented musician. He was a tall but very thin man with a slight stoop and a mournful look, which would disappear when he was drinking or playing his flute. His happiest moments came in the months after the harvest, when the village musicians would retrieve their instruments from above the fireplace. Unoka would join them, his face filled with pure joy and peace. Sometimes, other villages would invite Unoka and his band to teach them their tunes, and they would stay for several months, sharing their music.

text: At the Derby Avenue RC Basic School and St. George’s Anglican Basic School in Accra, invigilators were captured openly demanding GH¢60 daily tokens, supervisors pocketed envelopes of GH¢400, and candidates were asked to contribute to an Aseda Offertory. John Kapi stressed that once WAEC provides feedback on such incidents, it is the responsibility of the Ghana Education Service (GES) to take decisive action. And so when these issues come up, once the feedback goes to them, we [WAEC] expect that they would react appropriately and ensure that the right action is taken against the people, he said.
translated: [Ni kwa shule ya msingi ya Derby Avenue RC na St. George’s Anglican Basic School huko Accra, wafanyikazi wa uangalizi walipigwa picha wakidai waziwazi tokeni za kila siku za GH¢60, waangalizi walipakia kwenye mifuko ya GH¢400, na wanafunzi walitakiwa kuchangia Aseda Offertory. John Kapi alisisitiza kwamba mara WAEC inatoa maoni kuhusu matukio kama hayo, ni wajibu wa Huduma ya Elimu ya Ghana (GES) kuchukua hatua madhubuti. Na kwa hivyo wakati masuala haya yanapotokea, mara maoni yanapopatikana kwao, tuna [WAEC] matarajio kwamba watajibu ipasavyo na kuhakikisha kwamba hatua sahihi inachukuliwa dhidi ya watu hao, alisema.]
backtranslated: [At Derby Avenue RC Primary School and St. George's Anglican Basic School in Accra, administration staff were photographed demanding daily GH¢60 tokens, administrators were loaded into bags of GH¢400, and students were asked to contribute to the Aseda Offertory. John Kapi stressed that once the WAEC issues a statement on the incidents, it is the responsibility of the Ghana Education Service (GES) to take appropriate action. And so when these issues arise, when the statement is made, we [WAEC] expect that they will respond appropriately and ensure that appropriate action is taken against these people, he said.]

text: For rural communities in Ghana, especially in the Kumbungu district, access to and use of maternal healthcare services (MHCS) remain a significant challenge. This study set out to explore the specific barriers preventing women from utilizing these services and to evaluate the quality of care provided. The research adopted a mixed-methods approach, combining both quantitative and qualitative data to get a comprehensive view of the situation. This phased design involved surveying 441 pregnant and postpartum women and conducting interviews with 20 healthcare providers. A facility checklist was also used to assess the state of clinics, including the availability of essential drugs and equipment.
translated: [Mikarire ya kijijini ya Ghana, hasa katika wilaya ya Kumbungu, ufikiaji na matumizi ya huduma za afya ya uzazi (MHCS) bado ni changamoto kubwa. Utafiti huu ulilenga kuchunguza vizuizi maalum vinavyozuia wanawake kutumia huduma hizi na kutathmini ubora wa huduma iliyotolewa. Utafiti ulitumia mbinu ya mchanganyiko, ikichanganya data ya kiasi na ubora ili kupata mtazamo kamili wa hali hiyo. Muundo huu ulijumuisha kuuliza maswali kwa wanawake wajawazito na baada ya kujifungua 441 na kufanya mahojiano na watoa huduma za afya 20. Orodha ya kituo pia ilitumika kutathmini hali ya klinik, ikiwa ni pamoja na upatikanaji wa dawa muhimu na vifaa.]
backtranslated: [In rural Ghana, especially in Kumbungu district, access to and use of reproductive health services (MHCS) remains a major challenge. This study aims to examine the specific barriers that prevent women from accessing these services and assess the quality of the services provided. The study used a hybrid approach, combining quantitative and qualitative data to obtain a comprehensive picture of the situation. The framework included interviewing 441 pregnant and postpartum women and conducting interviews and providing 20 health services. The database was also used to assess the clinical status, including access to essential medicines and equipment.]

text: Okonkwo was a man of great renown throughout his nine villages and even beyond, a fame built entirely on his own remarkable achievements. At just eighteen years old, he brought honor to his village by defeating Amalinze the Cat, a legendary wrestler who had been undefeated for seven years. Amalinze earned his nickname because his back never once touched the earth. The old men of the village considered Okonkwo's victory one of the fiercest fights they had ever seen.

text: Muntaka assured the committee of full logistical and secretariat support from the Ministry and urged them to partner with civil society organizations, development partners, and faith-based institutions in carrying out their work. He described the task as heavy but honorable, stressing that the people of Gbenyiri and surrounding communities were looking up to the committee as instruments of peace, reconciliation, and healing.
translated: [Muntaka akawapa kamati ya uhakikisho wa usaidizi kamili wa kiufundi na usaidizi wa sekretariati kutoka kwa Wizara na kuwaomba kushirikiana na mashirika ya kiraia, washirika wa maendeleo, na taasisi za kidini katika kutekeleza kazi yao. Aliwasifu kazi hiyo kama nzito lakini ya heshima, akisisitiza kwamba watu wa Gbenyiri na jamii zinazozunguka walikuwa wakimtazama kamati kama zana za amani, upatanisho, na uponyaji.]
backtranslated: [The Minister assured the committee of the full technical assistance and secretarial support from the Ministry and asked them to cooperate with civil society organizations, development partners, and religious institutions in carrying out their work. He praised the work as difficult but dignified, stressing that the people of Gbenyiri and surrounding communities were looking forward to hundreds of committees for peace, reconciliation, and healing.]

text: The study also shed light on significant facility-based challenges that compromise the quality of care. A key issue was the inadequate number of midwives, which likely contributes to the long queues women reported. Additionally, the absence of essential equipment and drugs was a major problem. For example, health service providers specifically recommended a greater number of trained midwives and the provision of critical logistics like ultrasound machines and proper delivery equipment to ensure effective and high-quality care.
translated: [Ni kwa njia hii pia utafiti ulionyesha changamoto muhimu za kituo ambazo zinaharibu ubora wa huduma. Tatizo kuu lilikuwa idadi isiyo ya kutosha ya akina mama, ambayo ina uwezekano wa kuchangia katika mizunguko ndefu ambayo wanawake waliripoti. Zaidi ya hayo, ukosefu wa vifaa muhimu na dawa ulikuwa tatizo kubwa. Kwa mfano, watoa huduma za afya hasa walipendekeza kuwa na idadi kubwa ya akina mama waliofunzwa na upatikanaji wa vifaa muhimu kama vile mashine za kusikiliza sauti za moyo na vifaa vya kutosha vya kujifungulia ili kuhakikisha huduma bora na ya ubora wa juu.]
backtranslated: [It is also in this context that the study highlighted the key challenges of the facility that impacted the quality of care. The main problem was the insufficient number of mothers, which likely contributed to the long cycles that women reported. In addition, the lack of essential equipment and medication was a major problem. For example, health care providers specifically recommended that a large number of mothers be trained and have access to essential equipment such as heart-lung machines and adequate breathing apparatus to ensure quality and high-quality care.]

text: Okonkwo was an imposing figure, tall and massive with a severe expression, a result of his bushy eyebrows and wide nose. His breathing was so heavy that his family could hear it from their own houses when he slept. When he walked, his heels barely touched the ground, making him seem poised to pounce on someone—which he often did. He had a slight stammer, and in moments of anger, he would resort to his fists when words failed him. He had no patience for men who were not successful, and this sentiment stemmed from his deep-seated shame for his own father.
translated: [Okonkwo aarĩ mũndũ wa kũrĩa, mũũgi na mũthĩnĩ wa kũrĩa, na mũhũũro wa kũrĩa, mũhũũro wa kũrĩa wa kũrĩa, wa kũrĩa wa kũrĩa, wa kũrĩa wa kũrĩa, wa kũrĩa wa kũrĩa, wa kũrĩa wa kũrĩa, wa backtranslated: He was a man of sorrows and acquainted with grief; and like one from whom men hide their face, he was despised, and wept, and was mourned over, and was despised, and was despised, and was not known to men.

text: The West African Examinations Council (WAEC) says officials implicated in acts of corruption during the Basic Education Certificate Examination (BECE) will be blacklisted from ever taking part in its activities again. Speaking on JoyNews’ PM Express on September 8, WAEC’s Director of Public Affairs, John Kapi, said the Council cannot continue to work with individuals who have betrayed the trust placed in them during national examinations.
translated: [Kamati ya Mitihani ya Afrika ya Magharibi (WAEC) inasema maafisa waliotajwa katika vitendo vya rushwa wakati wa Mtihani wa Cheti cha Elimu ya Msingi (BECE) watapigwa marufuku kushiriki katika shughuli zake tena. Akizungumza kwenye PM Express ya JoyNews mnamo Septemba 8, Mkurugenzi wa Masuala ya Umma wa WAEC, John Kapi, alisema Kamati haiwezi kuendelea kufanya kazi na watu binafsi ambao wameuza imani iliyowekwa kwao wakati wa mitihani ya kitaifa.]
backtranslated: [The West African Examinations Council (WAEC) says officials implicated in corruption during the Basic Education Certificate Examination (BECE) are banned from participating in its activities again. Speaking on PM Express of JoyNews on September 8, the WAEC's Director of Public Affairs, John Kapi, said the Council cannot continue to work with individuals who have sold their faith to the state during national exams.]

text: The study found that while a high percentage of women did engage with some maternal health services—87.5% attended antenatal care (ANC), 87.3% had a skilled delivery, and 84.8% had a postnatal care (PNC) visit—the frequency of care was a concern. A little over half of the participants (53.4%) had the recommended four or more ANC visits, and nearly half (46.9%) didn't register until their second trimester. These figures highlight a gap between initial access and consistent, timely utilization of services, suggesting that women may be facing obstacles that prevent them from fully engaging with the healthcare system throughout their pregnancies.
translated: [Ni ukwenda wa utafiti ulionyesha kwamba ingawa asilimia kubwa ya wanawake walihusika na huduma fulani za afya ya uzazi—87.5% walihudhuria huduma ya kabla ya kujifungua (ANC), 87.3% walipata kujifungua kwa usaidizi wa mtaalamu, na 84.8% walipata huduma ya baada ya kujifungua (PNC) — marudio ya huduma yalikuwa suala la wasiwasi. Zaidi ya nusu ya washiriki (53.4%) walikuwa na ziara zinazopendekezwa za ANC nne au zaidi, na karibu nusu (46.9%) hawakujisajili hadi katika roboduara yao ya pili. Nambari hizi zinaangazia pengo kati ya ufikiaji wa awali na utumiaji wa mara kwa mara wa huduma, ikimaanisha kwamba wanawake wanaweza kukabiliana na vikwazo ambavyo vinawazuia kushiriki kikamilifu na mfumo wa huduma ya afya wakati wa ujauzito wao.]
backtranslated: [The survey findings showed that although a large percentage of women had access to some form of reproductive health services, 87.5% had attended antenatal care (ANC), 87.3% had experienced assisted delivery, and 84.8% had experienced postnatal care (PNC)  the return to services was a matter of concern. More than half of the participants (53.4%) had four or more scheduled ANC visits, and nearly half (46.9%) did not register until their second visit. These figures highlight the gap between women's access and immediate use of services, meaning women may begin to face barriers that prevent them from fully participating in the health care system during their pregnancy.]

text: The crowd held its breath as the drums beat and the flutes sang. Amalinze was a clever opponent, but Okonkwo was just as skilled, and as slippery as a fish in water. Both men were incredibly strong, their muscles and nerves straining to the point of almost breaking. But in the end, Okonkwo emerged victorious. This monumental win was just the beginning of his legacy. Over the next twenty years, his fame spread like a wildfire, fueled by his unwavering resolve and personal triumphs.
translated: [Andu aria ari na kuhota kwao kama ngoma zikikabia na filuti zikimbia. Amalinze alikuwa mpinzani mwenye busara, lakini Okonkwo alikuwa na ujuzi sawa, na kama samaki katika maji. Wanaume wote wawili walikuwa na nguvu kubwa sana, misuli na neva zao zikiwa katika hatari ya kuvunjika. Lakini mwishowe, Okonkwo alitoka mshindi. Ushindi huu mkubwa ulikuwa tu mwanzo wa urithi wake. Katika miaka ishirini iliyofuata, umaarufu wake ulienea kama moto wa kufua, uliochochewa na azimio lake lisiloegemea upande wowote na ushindi wake wa kibinafsi.]
backtranslated: [Their skills were like the devils flying and the elephants running. Amalinze was a cunning opponent, but Okonkwo was equally skilled, like a fish in water. Both men had tremendous strength, their muscles and nerves in danger of breaking. But in the end, Okonkwo emerged victorious. This great victory was only the beginning of his legacy. In the next twenty years, his fame spread like wildfire, fueled by his determination to remain neutral and his personal triumphs.]

text: The seven-member mediation committee will be chaired by Mr. Emmanuel Habuka Bombande. Other members of the committee include Alhaji Collins Dauda (MP and chair of the Committee on Lands and Natural Resource in Parliament), Rev. Father Lazarus Annyere (Chair of Savannah Regional Peace Council), Dr. Festus Aubyn (West Africa Network for Peace-building), Sylvia Hormane Noagbesenu Esq (Ag. Director of Women, Youth, Peace and Security Institute, Kofi Annan International Peacekeeping Training Center), Prof. Ramatu Alhassan and Dr. George Amoh (Ex. Sec. NPC) who will be the secretary.
translated: [Kamati ya kusuluhisha yenye wanachama saba itaongozwa na Bw. Emmanuel Habuka Bombande. Wanachama wengine wa kamati hii ni Alhaji Collins Dauda (MB na mwenyekiti wa Kamati ya Ardhi na Maliasili katika Bunge), Padre Lazarus Annyere (Mwenyekiti wa Baraza la Amani la Mkoa wa Savannah), Dkt. Festus Aubyn (Mtandao wa Ujenzi wa Amani wa Afrika Magharibi), Sylvia Hormane Noagbesenu Esq (Mkurugenzi wa Muda wa Wanawake, Vijana, Amani na Usalama, Kituo cha Mafunzo ya Amani ya Kimataifa cha Kofi Annan), Profesa Ramatu Alhassan na Dkt. George Amoh (Katibu Mkuu wa NPC) ambaye atakuwa katibu.]
backtranslated: [The seven-member mediation committee is chaired by Mr. Emmanuel Habuka Bombande. Other members of this committee are Alhaji Collins Dauda (MB and chairman of the Land and Natural Resources Committee in Parliament), Padre Lazarus Annyere (Chairman of the Peace Council of the Savannah Region), Dr. Festus Aubyn (West Africa Peacebuilding Network), Sylvia Hormane Noagbesenu Esq (Director of Women, Youth, Peace and Security, Kofi Annan International Peace Studies Center), Professor Ramatu Alhassan and Dr. George Amoh (NPC Secretary General) who will serve as secretary.]

text: To improve maternal health in the Kumbungu district, both study participants and service providers offered actionable recommendations. Women suggested focusing on public education about maternal care, enforcing free MHCS, and improving the local road network to make facilities more accessible. Providers emphasized the need for more midwives and better equipment. The study concludes that both governmental and non-governmental organizations must increase investment in maternal health and address the broader socioeconomic issues affecting women. This comprehensive approach, tackling both healthcare system deficiencies and community-level barriers, is essential for truly improving maternal health outcomes.
translated: [Kuiga mbere afya ya wanawake katika eneo la Kumbungu, wachunguzi na watoa huduma walitoa mapendekezo yanayoweza kutekelezwa. Wanawake walipendekeza kuzingatia elimu ya umma kuhusu huduma za uzazi, kutekeleza huduma za afya za uzazi bila malipo, na kuboresha mtandao wa barabara za ndani ili kufanya vituo vya huduma kuwa rahisi kufikiwa. Watoa huduma walisisitiza hitaji la midwife zaidi na vifaa bora zaidi. Utafiti unahitimisha kwamba mashirika ya serikali na yasiyo ya serikali lazima ongeze uwekezaji katika afya ya uzazi na kushughulikia masuala mapana ya kiuchumi na kijamii yanayoathiri wanawake. Mbinu hii ya kina, inayoshughulikia kasoro za mfumo wa huduma za afya na vikwazo vya kiwango cha jamii, ni muhimu kwa kweli kuboresha matokeo ya afya ya uzazi.]
backtranslated: [To promote women's health in the Kumbungu area, researchers and health care providers made practical recommendations. Women recommended focusing on public education about reproductive services, implementing free reproductive health services, and improving the local road network to make service stations more accessible. Health care providers emphasized the need for more midwives and better facilities. Research suggests that government and non-government organizations should increase investment in reproductive health and address a range of socioeconomic issues affecting women. This new approach, which addresses the shortcomings of the health care system and the barriers to quality, is indeed crucial to improving reproductive health outcomes for the community.]

text: Unoka, Okonkwo's father, had passed away ten years prior. He was a man known for his laziness and carelessness, living only for the present with no thought for the future. Any money he managed to acquire—which was a rare occurrence—he would immediately spend on palm-wine, gathering his neighbors for a celebration. He believed that to see a dead man's mouth was to see the foolishness of not eating what you had in life. Unoka was also deeply in debt, owing money to nearly every one of his neighbors.
translated: [Unoka, baba wa Okonkwo, alikufa miaka kumi iliyopita. Alikuwa mtu anayejulikana kwa uvivu wake na kutokuwa na tahadhari, akiishi tu kwa ajili ya sasa bila kufikiria kuhusu siku zijazo. Fedha yoyote aliyoweza kupata—jambo ambalo halikuwa la kawaida—alitumia mara moja kwa ajili ya mvinyo wa mchikichi, akiwaleta majirani wake kwa ajili ya sherehe. Alikuwa na imani kwamba kuona mdomo wa mgonjwa ni kuona ujinga wa kutokula kilicho nacho maishani. Unoka pia alikuwa na deni kubwa, akiwa na deni kwa majirani wake wengi.]
backtranslated: [Unoka, Okonkwo's father, died ten years ago. He was a man known for his laziness and carelessness, living only for the present without thinking about the future. Any money he could get - a rather unusual phrase - he used immediately for wedding wine, bringing his neighbors for the feast. He believed that seeing the mouth of the sick was a sign of the folly of not eating anything in life. Unoka was also heavily in debt, owing a lot of his neighbors.]
